html:
2.27.18  3:58 pm   2.26.18  7:00 pm I don't believe in free will because I feel like we're all just reacting in the way we were set up to react by prior things reacting, like an equation.

      It shouldn't matter, really, but it feels like it matters, which is why I would enjoy believing in free will.

4.15.17  11:26 pm   Was making the decision to start making HotEWIG a hard one? Many people procastinate for a long time before doing a project that they have wanted to do for a long time because they're afraid of screwing it up, did you do so?

     there has been no procrastination of any kind whatsoever since early 2014. but i spent a long time doing short videos to make sure i knew what i was doing before doing longer projects. and then just when i was ready to move to longer projects, i got stuck doing shorter projects for a different reason

html:
2.20.18  8:02 pm   2.19.18  11:02 pm I agree and think that music theory should not be taught alongside music. Do you think that it is at all useful?


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201802192302

2.19.18  11:02 pm   f u c k the phrase 'music theory'. it makes me so uncomfortable,

     me too, it's a deceptive phrase, and it is all too often conflated with literacy

      music is a thing that you make and learn and experience with your soul and ears and stuff,

     oh hell true

     'music theory' makes it sound like music is something that's meant to be approached like it's political science or some shit.

     exactly

      do i make sense?

     yes

     what are ur thoughts the phrase 'music theory'?

     the phrase makes me vomit in my mouth, and it's a big challenge each time to restrain from vomiting in other people's mouths as well. thankfully, over the years, working closely with my therapist i have found a decent strategy for how to respond to that phrase

html:
2.17.18  2:21 pm   in hotewig, why did you feel the need to include that the sultan of oman lives in zanzibar now?

5.24.17  8:50 pm
embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201705242050a

5.24.17  8:50 pm   Hey, it's me, person watching your videos everyday. So, I'm wondering, why did you bring up the sultan of Oman living in Zanzibar? It's pretty funny but seems unrelated to everything else. One of my favourite things about the video is how you make history into an interrelated narrative in which everything mentioned is important. But the Sultan thing seems super random. Thanks!

     there are hundreds, thousands of things that happened in world history, so needless to say it was an insane challenge to figure out what to include and what to cut, and a never ending impossible balancing act. to help stay upbeat and sane in this project, i found it important early on to keep a very light and free attitude about the whole thing. people are surely going to get on my case for 'not mentioning this' and 'not mentioning that,' you can't mention everything that ever happened in one video. so the only way to really keep my shit together was just remember that this is a crazy thing to attempt, so just keep it fun, and don't be afraid to include weird things on purpose, just as a reminder that this is supposed to be fun, to hopefully distract from the fact that it is impossible to actually mention everything. the oman jingle was written in an early draft, and then got cut along with a million other things, but i liked the jingle so much i brought it back. trying to keep the whole thing perfectly balanced with an equal amount of details everywhere is kind of like drawing a straight line in a hurricane. at some point you have to just accept that certain random things are going to have extra details. also once a bit is written and turns out good, it can be hard to let go of. other examples would include the chandragupta/seleucis elephant deal, the robespierre stuff, etc. i had a hundred years war bit that i liked so much i was so sad to cut it, but there was surely already way too much britain/france in the video, and the first thing people usually complain about in history videos is that there's too much europe. so i had to cut it
original_html:
2.17.18  2:21 pm   in hotewig, why did you feel the need to include that the sultan of oman lives in zanzibar now?

5.24.17  8:50 pm

answers_original.html:
5.24.17  8:50 pm   Hey, it's me, person watching your videos everyday. So, I'm wondering, why did you bring up the sultan of Oman living in Zanzibar? It's pretty funny but seems unrelated to everything else. One of my favourite things about the video is how you make history into an interrelated narrative in which everything mentioned is important. But the Sultan thing seems super random. Thanks!

     there are hundreds, thousands of things that happened in world history, so needless to say it was an insane challenge to figure out what to include and what to cut, and a never ending impossible balancing act. to help stay upbeat and sane in this project, i found it important early on to keep a very light and free attitude about the whole thing. people are surely going to get on my case for 'not mentioning this' and 'not mentioning that,' you can't mention everything that ever happened in one video. so the only way to really keep my shit together was just remember that this is a crazy thing to attempt, so just keep it fun, and don't be afraid to include weird things on purpose, just as a reminder that this is supposed to be fun, to hopefully distract from the fact that it is impossible to actually mention everything. the oman jingle was written in an early draft, and then got cut along with a million other things, but i liked the jingle so much i brought it back. trying to keep the whole thing perfectly balanced with an equal amount of details everywhere is kind of like drawing a straight line in a hurricane. at some point you have to just accept that certain random things are going to have extra details. also once a bit is written and turns out good, it can be hard to let go of. other examples would include the chandragupta/seleucis elephant deal, the robespierre stuff, etc. i had a hundred years war bit that i liked so much i was so sad to cut it, but there was surely already way too much britain/france in the video, and the first thing people usually complain about in history videos is that there's too much europe. so i had to cut it

html:
2.16.18  10:02 am   hey bill how the hell do people not see you use capital letters few examples are right on this page 2.15.18  12:27 pm 2.15.18  12:55 pm


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201802151227

2.15.18  12:27 pm   hi, my name is jada. anyways, i have finally gotten to a point where my creativity is eating me alive. I have to make something soon. I need to. The issue? I don't have access to the things I need to create what I want to create. And the things I do have access to haven't satisfied my creative urges in any big way. What do I need to do now?

     look around and maybe you can find something easy and simple to use. keep an open mind, you never know what it might be. you can do creative things with almost anything

      Continuing waiting until I have access to what I really need

     you don't know yet what that is

      or should I figure out something completely new that I can do with the things I have access to?

     ALWAYS do that

      what if that isn't sufficient? 

     it's not time to ask that yet, but almost anything you have will be at least sufficient to exercise your abilities a little bit and learn further about how you work and might like to work. then you can look around a bit and surely have a slightly better idea of where you're going, and what you might be looking for


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201802151255

2.15.18  12:55 pm   2.14.18  1:10 pm When you say "above middle C," do you say it because there's something special about that pitch

     not that pitch exactly but i said that one because it has a special name so it's easy to say. generally anything above about A220 seems to be fine for vocal harmonies

     or because of where it sits in your vocal range (i. e., the timbre of those notes when sung by bill wurtz)?

     has nothing to do with me

      I personally have a voice much lower than yours and can't sing much above middle C without either yelling or going into falsetto. Would that guideline still apply in my case?

     generally

     How would it change?

     someone asked something like 'why do my vocal harmonies sound yucky', or something like that. without hearing them, it's impossible to say exactly, but i just thought i would give a few tips of some perhaps common reasons why beginners might have trouble with this. one being the volume, the other being the range

     or because of where it sits in your vocal range (i. e., the timbre of those notes when sung by bill wurtz)?

      I personally have a voice much lower than yours and can't sing much above middle C without either yelling or going into falsetto. Would that guideline still apply in my case?

     How would it change?


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201802141310

2.14.18  1:10 pm   How do you sound so good harmonizing with yourself? Whenever I do my own harmonies it always sounds so gross.

     experience, but here's some cool hints. make sure the harmony tracks are quite low volume compared to the lead. also make sure most of your notes are above middle c. also make sure they're in tune. if you can't sing it in tune, you can always ask the computer to put it in tune for you. you'll lose your bragging rights but everyone does it and even if you don't it's impossible to prove you don't

html:
2.9.18  3:13 pm   Some of the songs I've written actually began as two separate song ideas, which I then combined. Initially, I'll feel good about the final product. But then I'll get anxious, wondering if others will hear it as one natural song, or as a Frankenstein song of disparate ideas stitched together. *Or,* the middle ground-- one song that does something unexpected, interesting and positive. I'm too "close" to it to get perspective. Have you ever encountered any of this? Any thoughts or suggestions?

6.15.17  1:20 am
embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201706150120

6.15.17  1:20 am   have you considered combining some of the song ideas on your list to get through it more effectively? i mean, if they were deemed worthy to write down for posterity, they're certainly already good ideas and concepts, and putting these ideas together might also streamline the writing process a bit

     in my experience, combining songs is not a good strategy. each song has its own very unique needs and it is important to consider exactly what that song needs in order to make it the strongest song. combining 2 halfwritten songs would be kind of like combining 2 half built houses and hoping it makes sense. although i suppose it may work for some people, and i think that's great. the last time i revealed here that i don't combine songs someone got mad at me. so it is important to emphasize the fact that other people may have success in doing that but it is not something that i think makes sense for me

html:
2.2.18  8:49 am   I love how your stuff *sounds*. It seems that you do this by yourself, with modest material means. Do you spend a lot of time recording/mixing/mastering/crafting the sound, or do you have some kind of established routine that makes it fast? I'm kind of asking for "mixing tips from bill", because I find it very hard to get a "sound that I like" all by myself. I tend to get discouraged quickly, despite the fact that I know that the best advice is probably "keep crafting until you like it".


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201706131757

6.13.17  5:57 pm   Dude, the new songs are great, and that was kinda to be expected but... what are you doing differently for the mixes? They sound better than ever in your stuff, I think!

     my process goes like this. listen to it on as many different speakers / sound sources as i can, and compare it to a current top40 track. then contemplate suicide for a while. then gradually troubleshoot and mess with the eq of the bass, kick, percussion, etc and maybe pull some mids out of a vocal line here and there, and then panic about the loudness and then go hunt down all the peaks, especially the "S"s, and then who knows, maybe it might sound ok after that
original_html: 2.2.18  8:49 am   I love how your stuff *sounds*. It seems that you do this by yourself, with modest material means. Do you spend a lot of time recording/mixing/mastering/crafting the sound, or do you have some kind of established routine that makes it fast? I'm kind of asking for "mixing tips from bill", because I find it very hard to get a "sound that I like" all by myself. I tend to get discouraged quickly, despite the fact that I know that the best advice is probably "keep crafting until you like it".

answers_original.html:
6.13.17  5:57 pm   Dude, the new songs are great, and that was kinda to be expected but... what are you doing differently for the mixes? They sound better than ever in your stuff, I think!

     my process goes like this. listen to it on as many different speakers / sound sources as i can, and compare it to a current top40 track. then contemplate suicide for a while. then gradually troubleshoot and mess with the eq of the bass, kick, percussion, etc and maybe pull some mids out of a vocal line here and there, and then panic about the loudness and then go hunt down all the peaks, especially the "S"s, and then who knows, maybe it might sound ok after that

html:
1.31.18  9:20 pm   1.29.18  2:07 pm Hey, just want to say thanks! I tried your suggestion and randomizing the hits/rests with the triplets has been super helpful. I also have this app on my phone that's like a metronome but you can plug in the specific rhythm notation, so I've been doing that to check to make sure my timing is good. Couple more questions about this whole thing. Are triplets almost always going going to be grouped in 3's?  Maybe its not really common cause I'm not seeing it in any of my sheet music, but would you ever see something like one eighth note/rest triplet just by itself immediately followed by a 'regular', non-triplet note/rest?

      And will triplets almost always start right at the top of the beat, like would you ever see 3 quarter note triplets, but starting on the "and" of the beat? How would you count out stuff where you kind of have to subdivide a single beat into 3's as well as into 2's or 4 's for regular eighth or sixteenth notes? (sorry if this is all jumbled, I hope you understand what I mean though).


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201801291407

1.29.18  2:07 pm   Can you maybe lend a hand with this? I can sight read rhythms fine when it's just combinations of whole/half/quarter/8ths/16th notes (with rests or dots or ties or whatever)... But I get thrown off whenever triplets (or some kind of tuplet) comes in to play. I can clap out quarter note triplets or eighth note triplets over a click, but when it comes in the middle of a measure, or on an offbeat, or if there's only just one or two (instead of 3) of the triplets or if you have the triplets tied together with other notes, or a quarter note triplet paired with an eighth note triplet... all that kind of stuff just throws me off. I guess I kind of internalized the triplets in groups of 3 (three 8th note or 3 quarter note triplets in a line starting on the downbeat) and when they don't fall like that, I just can't feel the rhythm. Do you have any tips for how to count this stuff, or better yet just like how to internalize the feel of the notes to make them c ome more easy and natural? Ideally, I just want to get to the point where I can just feel it and play it naturally and don't have to be counting continuously in my head when trying to read. Just like when playing for fun, or making my own music I'm feeling the pulses of the bar, but I'm not counting all the subdivisions just letting the rhythms come naturally. I feel like I'm probably using all these tuplets a lot in my own playing and not even realizing when I'm doing it. 

     if you are familiar with the "1 & 2 & 3 & 4 &" system for counting 8th notes, or the "1e&a2e&a3e&a4e&a" system for counting 16th notes, imagine a system of "1-trip-let-2-trip-let-3-trip-let-4-trip-let" for counting triplets. this should help you subdivide. for example, the sort of west african triplet clave rhythm would be 1 _ let (2) trip-let (3) _ let (4) _ _. write out some random combinations of triplets, and practice counting like this. maybe even go to random dot org and get a string of 12 binary digits, and say the 1's are where the notes are and the 0's are where the spaces are. write it out as triplets (that will give you writing practice) and then read it (that will give you reading practice.)

How would you count out stuff where you kind of have to subdivide a single beat into 3's as well as into 2's or 4 's for regular eighth or sixteenth notes? (sorry if this is all jumbled, I hope you understand what I mean though).

I guess I kind of internalized the triplets in groups of 3 (three 8th note or 3 quarter note triplets in a line starting on the downbeat) and when they don't fall like that, I just can't feel the rhythm. Just like when playing for fun, or making my own music I'm feeling the pulses of the bar, but I'm not counting all the subdivisions just letting the rhythms come naturally. I feel like I'm probably using all these tuplets a lot in my own playing and not even realizing when I'm doing it. 

     if you are familiar with the "1 & 2 & 3 & 4 &" system for counting 8th notes, or the "1e&a2e&a3e&a4e&a" system for counting 16th notes, imagine a system of "1-trip-let-2-trip-let-3-trip-let-4-trip-let" for counting triplets. this should help you subdivide. for example, the sort of west african triplet clave rhythm would be 1 _ let (2) trip-let (3) _ let (4) _ _. write out some random combinations of triplets, and practice counting like this. maybe even go to random dot org and get a string of 12 binary digits, and say the 1's are where the notes are and the 0's are where the spaces are. write it out as triplets (that will give you writing practice) and then read it (that will give you reading practice.)

html:
1.31.18  8:17 am   i'm curious about the creative process behin "blades of grass" 

1.27.18  7:17 pm
embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201801271917

1.27.18  7:17 pm   What is your process for making a video?

     first figure out how it should go, then figure out how to make it go how i said it should go. then do what i said i should do to make it go how i think it should go. then look at it and freak out because it's not going how i thought it should go. then make a list of adjustments i can make to try to get it to go the way i want it to go. then do what it says on the list. then make another smaller list, and do that list. then make an even smaller list, and do what's on that list. then make an even smaller list and skip that list, and post it online
